articles.headline: How China Has Added to Its Influence Over the iPhone
articles.snippet: Apple is taking small steps toward India. But the production of its latest phone, introduced on Wednesday, shows how difficult it will be to make big changes.
articles.abstract: Apple is taking small steps toward India. But the production of its latest phone, introduced on Wednesday, shows how difficult it will be to make big changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: This fall, Apple will make some of its flagship iPhones outside China for the first time, a small but significant change for a company that has built one of the most sophisticated supply chains in the world with the help of the Chinese authorities. But the development of the iPhone 14, which was unveiled on Wednesday, shows how complicated it will be for Apple to truly untangle itself from China.

articles.headline: ‘Playing With Fire’: U.N. Team Calls for No-Fire Zone at Ukraine Nuclear Plant
articles.snippet: In a highly anticipated report, nuclear experts who crossed a battlefield to inspect Europe’s largest nuclear plant called for Russia and Ukraine to halt all military activity around the complex.
articles.abstract: In a highly anticipated report, nuclear experts who crossed a battlefield to inspect Europe’s largest nuclear plant called for Russia and Ukraine to halt all military activity around the complex.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United Nations’ nuclear watchdog on Tuesday called for a no-fire zone around an embattled Ukrainian nuclear generator, but like the plant itself, the agency was quickly caught up in the war between Russia and Ukraine.
articles.byline: By Eric Nagourney and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

articles.headline: Europe Is Sacrificing Its Ancient Forests for Energy
articles.snippet: Governments bet billions on burning timber for green power. The Times went deep into one of the continent’s oldest woodlands to track the hidden cost.
articles.abstract: Governments bet billions on burning timber for green power. The Times went deep into one of the continent’s oldest woodlands to track the hidden cost.
articles.lead_paragraph: Governments bet billions on burning timber for green power. The Times went deep into one of the continent’s oldest woodlands to track the hidden cost.
articles.byline: By Sarah Hurtes and Weiyi Cai

articles.headline: Clean Energy Projects Surge After Climate Bill Passage
articles.snippet: Investments in battery factories, solar panel manufacturing and mining will help the Biden administration meet targets for reducing greenhouse gases.
articles.abstract: Investments in battery factories, solar panel manufacturing and mining will help the Biden administration meet targets for reducing greenhouse gases.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the weeks since President Biden signed a comprehensive climate bill devised to spur investment in electric cars and clean energy, corporations have announced a series of big-ticket projects to produce the kind of technology the legislation aims to promote.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Ivan Penn

articles.headline: From Boom to Gloom: Tech Recruiters Struggle to Find Work
articles.snippet: As tech companies slow hiring and lay off workers, once-busy recruiters are shifting to other roles and cutting their rates.
articles.abstract: As tech companies slow hiring and lay off workers, once-busy recruiters are shifting to other roles and cutting their rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seemingly overnight, the tech industry flipped from aggressive growth, hiring sprees, lavish perks and boundless opportunity to layoffs, hiring freezes and doing more with less.

articles.headline: The Supply Chain Broke. Robots Are Supposed to Help Fix It.
articles.snippet: The companies behind e-commerce are embracing automation as the means of transcending the limitations of humans.
articles.abstract: The companies behind e-commerce are embracing automation as the means of transcending the limitations of humans.
articles.lead_paragraph: The people running companies that deliver all manner of products gathered in Philadelphia last week to sift through the lessons of the mayhem besieging the global supply chain. At the center of many proposed solutions: robots and other forms of automation.

articles.headline: In Voter Fraud, Penalties Often Depend on Who’s Voting
articles.snippet: Cases in Florida and a survey of prosecutions nationally indicate that despite the furor over voter fraud, prosecutions remain exceedingly rare and penalties vary wildly.
articles.abstract: Cases in Florida and a survey of prosecutions nationally indicate that despite the furor over voter fraud, prosecutions remain exceedingly rare and penalties vary wildly.
articles.lead_paragraph: After 15 years of scrapes with the police, the last thing that 33-year-old Therris L. Conney needed was another run-in with the law. He got one anyway two years ago, after election officials held a presentation on voting rights for inmates of the county jail in Gainesville, Fla.

articles.headline: China’s ‘Zero Covid’ Bind: No Easy Way Out Despite the Cost
articles.snippet: From vaccines to propaganda, Beijing has prioritized politics over science, creating conditions that make it difficult for China to join other countries in adapting to life with the coronavirus.
articles.abstract: From vaccines to propaganda, Beijing has prioritized politics over science, creating conditions that make it difficult for China to join other countries in adapting to life with the coronavirus.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tens of millions of Chinese confined at home, schools closed, businesses in limbo and whole cities at a standstill. Once again, China is locking down enormous parts of society, trying to completely eradicate Covid in a campaign that grows more anomalous by the day as the rest of the world learns to live with the coronavirus.

articles.headline: Europe Says Putin’s Gas Power Is Weakening
articles.snippet: In Germany and elsewhere, leaders are growing more confident that months of work to stockpile and line up alternate energy sources may help them blunt Russia’s weaponization of exports.
articles.abstract: In Germany and elsewhere, leaders are growing more confident that months of work to stockpile and line up alternate energy sources may help them blunt Russia’s weaponization of exports.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Not long after Russian forces invaded Ukraine, another mobilization began. European energy ministers and diplomats started jetting across the world and inking energy deals — racing to prepare for a rough winter should Russia choose to cut off its cheap gas in retaliation for Western sanctions.
articles.byline: By Melissa Eddy, Erika Solomon and Anton Troianovski
